name: Electrical Panel Upgrade (100A to 200A)
description: Modern electrical demands often exceed the capacity of older residential systems. Solomon Electric specializes in upgrading 100-amp panels to 200-amp service, providing the necessary capacity for central air conditioning, electric vehicle charging, and smart home technology while complying with current Florida building and insurance standards.
features: Full coordination with utility providers for service upgrades
Installation of modern code-compliant electrical panels
Integration of whole-home surge protection equipment
Decommissioning of outdated or hazardous panel brands
Provision of electrical certification for insurance verification
Adherence to National Electrical Code (NEC) standards
warningSignsSubheading: Older electrical infrastructure in Florida properties can lead to operational limitations and safety risks. These indicators suggest the need for a system evaluation.

problems.title: Insurance Capacity Requirements
problems.description: Florida insurance policies frequently require the modernization of electrical panels that are over 30 years old to maintain property coverage eligibility.

problems.title: Hazardous Manufacturer Brands
problems.description: Certain legacy panel brands have a history of mechanical failure and are recognized as safety hazards within the electrical and insurance industries.

problems.title: Corrosion and Thermal Damage
problems.description: Environmental exposure in coastal areas can cause internal corrosion and white residue inside panels, leading to poor connections and heat buildup.

problems.title: EV Charging Readiness
problems.description: A 100-amp service is often insufficient to support the continuous high-amperage load of a Level 2 electric vehicle charger alongside other appliances.

problems.title: Voltage Fluctuations during high demand
problems.description: Visible dimming of lights when high-demand appliances like air conditioners activate suggest the existing service is reaching its functional limit.

problems.title: Obsolete Overcurrent Protection
problems.description: Fuse-based systems and early circuit breakers lack the modern safety features such as arc-fault and ground-fault protection found in new panels.

process.title: Load Calculation
process.description: A technician performs an NEC load calculation to determine the optimal service size based on the property's total electrical footprint.

process.title: Administrative Coordination
process.description: The necessary electrical permits are secured with municipal building departments and engineering requests are submitted to the utility company.

process.title: Physical Installation
process.description: The existing service entrance and panel are replaced with a high-performance 200-amp system, including the main breaker and branch circuits.

process.title: Municipal Inspection
process.description: A city electrical inspector reviews the new installation to verify compliance with local codes and safety regulations prior to service reconnection.

process.title: Documentation Finalization
process.description: The property owner is provided with the final permit documents and safety certifications required for property records and insurance agents.

benefits.title: Regulatory Compliance
benefits.description: Modern 200-amp panels are designed to meet current insurance requirements and pass standard 4-point inspections for South Florida properties.

benefits.title: Enhanced Circuit Protection
benefits.description: Newer panels include integrated Arc-Fault (AFCI) and Ground-Fault (GFCI) protection to mitigate risk of fire and electrical shock.

benefits.title: Infrastructure Scalability
benefits.description: Increasing service capacity to 200-amps provides the foundation for future electrical additions such as solar, EV chargers, or smart home hubs.

benefits.title: System Reliability
benefits.description: Replacing aged components reduces the frequency of tripped breakers and improves the overall stability of the electrical system.

faqs.question: Why is an upgrade required for insurance purposes?
faqs.answer: Insurance carriers in Florida prioritize safety and have identified older electrical panels as higher risk for claims. A 200-amp modernization is often the standard requirement for maintaining full property coverage.

faqs.question: Is service interrupted during the upgrade?
faqs.answer: Yes, electrical service is temporarily disconnected during the physical transfer of the service entrance and panel and is restored following municipal inspection approval.

faqs.question: What is the primary difference between legacy and modern panels?
faqs.answer: Modern panels offer higher amperage capacity and advanced circuit protection technology that was not available in older models, ensuring the system can handle current home loads safely.

faqs.question: Are older panel brands still considered functional?
faqs.answer: While they may deliver power, certain legacy brands have a high failure rate in critical safety tests and are no longer recommended for continued use in residential settings.

faqs.question: Is surge protection included in a panel upgrade?
faqs.answer: Current Florida building codes often require the integration of surge protection during a panel modernization to safeguard the electrical system from internal and external voltage spikes.

seoContent.heading: Electrical Panel Modernization in Miami-Dade & Broward
seoContent.body: Expert electrical panel upgrades are provided throughout South Florida, specializing in the conversion of older residential infrastructure to modern 200-amp service standards. Our technicians manage the requirements for municipal permitting and utility coordination to ensure a compliant modernization.

seoContent.heading: Replacement of Obsolete Residential Panels
seoContent.body: Many properties in Miami and surrounding areas still utilize outdated electrical panels that are recognized as liabilities by safety organizations and insurance providers. Professional replacement with modern equipment is used to bring properties into compliance with the latest safety standards.
